snippet: A plan to skirt Russia’s state energy behemoth, Gazprom, by reverse-flowing natural gas into Ukraine has been hindered by reluctance from neighboring Slovakia, seemingly due to pressure from the Russian company.
abstract: Ukraine's effort to establish 'reverse flow' gas imports from Europe has been consistently thwarted by reluctant Slovakia, essential gas corridor between country and continent; plan would allow Ukraine to break free of Russia's state-controlled energy giant Gazprom, which has raised prices and threatened to turn off tap since unrest between two countries began; analysts see Slovakian intransigence as evidence of Gazprom's outsize political influence across Europe.

byline.contributor: Hana de Goeij contributed reporting from Prague, and Alison Smale from Berlin.

lead_paragraph: A plan to skirt Russia’s state energy behemoth, Gazprom, by reverse-flowing natural gas into Ukraine has been hindered by reluctance from neighboring Slovakia, seemingly due to pressure from the Russian company.

headline.main: Kiev Struggles to Break Russia’s Grip on Gas Flow
headline.print_headline: Kiev Struggles to Break Russia’s Grip on Gas Flow
